skills.name: Add proper fractions with different denominators where one is a multiple of the other
Add fractions involving improper fractions with different denominators
Subtract proper fractions with different denominators which do not share a common factor
Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Fraction
Answer fraction problems that require the use of addition and subtraction

explanations.A: To add fractions they must have the same denominator. 7/4 + 7/5 = 35/20 + 28/20 = 63/20. Then converting to a mixed number 63/20 = 60/20 + 3/20 = 3 and 3/20. This is bigger than 3. So only Tom is correct.
explanations.B: Not quite. Before adding fractions we must make them have the same denominator. Try using 20 for the lowest common denominator.
explanations.C: Not quite. Before adding fractions we must make them have the same denominator. Try using 20 for the lowest common denominator.
explanations.D: One of them has to be correct. Remember that > means greater than and < means less than.

explanations.A: Not quite. Before adding fractions we must make them have the same denominator. Try using 30 for the lowest common denominator.
explanations.B: Not quite. Before adding fractions we must make them have the same denominator. Try using 30 for the lowest common denominator.
explanations.C: To add fractions they must have the same denominator. 11/6 + 9/5 = 55/30 + 54/30 = 109/30. Then converting to a mixed number 109/30 = 90/30 + 19/30 = 3 and 19/30. This is bigger than 3 and less than 4. They are both correct
explanations.D: One of them has to be correct. Remember that > means greater than and < means less than.

explanations.A: It looks like you have worked out the full calculation. Find the value of the star only.
explanations.B: It looks like you have added the numerators and denominators. To add fractions they must have the same denominator first.
explanations.C: It looks like you multiplied rather than added the fractions.
explanations.D: Applying the Distributive Law means that for the right-hand side, ★ will take the value of 1/8 ＋ 3/4. Putting these over a common denominator gives 1/8 ＋ 6/8 = 7/8

explanations.A: It looks like you have added the numerators and denominators. To add fractions they must have the same denominator first.
explanations.B: It looks like you have worked out the full calculation. Find the value of the star only.
explanations.C: Applying the Distributive Law means that for the right-hand side, ★ will take the value of 3/5 ＋ 7/10. Putting these over a common denominator gives 6/10 ＋ 7/10 = 13/10
explanations.D: It looks like you multiplied rather than added the fractions.

explanations.A: To add or subtract fractions we need a common denominator. 12 is a multiple of 2, 3 and 4. So 1/2 - 3/4 + 2/3 = 6/12 - 9/12 + 8/12. Working from left to right gives 5/12.
explanations.B: It looks like you have added and subtracted the numerators and denominators. To add or subtract fractions they must have the same denominator first.
explanations.C: It looks like you subtracted the final fraction instead of adding it.
explanations.D: It looks like you have made an error with your signs. Recheck your calculations carefully.

explanations.A: It looks like you subtracted the final fraction instead of adding it.
explanations.B: It looks like you have added and subtracted the numerators and denominators. To add or subtract fractions they must have the same denominator first.
explanations.C: To add or subtract fractions we need a common denominator. 20 is a multiple of 4, 5 and 10. So 3/4 - 2/5 + 1/10 = 15/20 - 8/20 + 2/20. Working from left to right gives 9/20.
explanations.D: It looks like you have an error in your calculations. Recheck these carefully.

explanations.A: Not quite. The side lengths on the right (the star and 1/3 m) must equal the side lengths on the left (3/4 m).
explanations.B: 1/3 ＋ ★ = 3/4. So subtracting 1/3 from both sides gives ★ = 3/4 − 1/3 = 9/12 − 4/12 = 5/12 m.
explanations.C: Not quite. The side lengths on the right (the star and 1/3 m) must equal the side lengths on the left (3/4 m).
explanations.D: Not quite. The side lengths on the right (the star and 1/3 m) must equal the side lengths on the left (3/4 m).

explanations.A: Not quite. The side lengths on the right (the star and 1/4 m) must equal the side lengths on the left (2/3 m).
explanations.B: Not quite. The side lengths on the right (the star and 1/4 m) must equal the side lengths on the left (2/3 m).
explanations.C: 1/4 ＋ ★ = 2/3. So subtracting 1/4 from both sides gives ★ = 2/3 − 1/4 = 8/12 − 3/12 = 5/12 m.
explanations.D: Not quite. The side lengths on the right (the star and 1/4 m) must equal the side lengths on the left (2/3 m).

explanations.A: area of a rectangle = width ✕ height = 1/2 ✕ 3/4 = (1 ✕ 3)/(2 ✕ 4) = 3/8 square metres.
explanations.B: It looks like you have done the wrong calculation. What is the width of P? What is the height of P?
explanations.C: It looks like you have done the wrong calculation. What is the width of P? What is the height of P?
explanations.D: It looks like you have added rather than multiplied two of the fractions.

explanations.A: It looks like you have done the wrong calculation. What is the width of Q? What is the height of Q?
explanations.B: It looks like you have done the wrong calculation. What is the width of Q? What is the height of Q?
explanations.C: It looks like you have added rather than multiplied two of the fractions.
explanations.D: area of a rectangle = width ✕ height= 1/2 ✕ 2/3 = (1 ✕ 2)/(2 ✕ 3) = 2/6 = 1/3 square metres.
